title: 114_hr4042
content: The Act may be cited as the "Pre-K for USA Act." The findings are also included in the Act. The United States ranks 25th in early learning enrollment, with less than 3 out of 10 four-year-olds in high-quality prekindergarten programs. Studies show that access to such programs reduces grade repetition and dropout rates, leading to career success. Every public dollar spent on prekindergarten programs yields a $7 return by reducing the need for remedial education and special services. Prekindergarten programs yield a $7 return by reducing spending on remedial education, grade repetition, and special education. Children who attend prekindergarten are less likely to develop drug problems, commit felonies, or go to prison, and have higher GPAs. Around 40% of school districts do not offer prekindergarten programs. Texas missed out on up to $118.48 million in Federal funding to expand prekindergarten programs due to budget cuts in education funding by the Texas legislature in 2011. The State of Texas missed out on up to $118.48 million in Federal funding for prekindergarten programs due to education budget cuts in 2011. Local governments responded by funding full-day prekindergarten programs, prompting the need for direct application to Federal prekindergarten program funding for certain localities. SEC. 3. PREKINDERGARTEN DEVELOPMENT GRANTS. The Secretary of Education, in consultation with the Secretary of Health and Human Services, will award competitive grants to increase capacity for high-quality prekindergarten programs. Grants will be awarded for up to 3 years and will not be renewed. Applicants include Governors, chief executive officers of States, local educational agencies, or other local government entities. To apply for a grant under this Act, a State or local government entity must submit an application to the Secretary of Education. States must consult with the State Advisory Council on Early Childhood Education and Care when developing their grant applications. Eligibility for a grant is subject to a matching requirement. To be eligible for a grant under this Act, a State, local educational agency, or other local government entity must contribute non-Federal matching funds equal to at least 20 percent of the grant amount. These funds can come from non-Federal resources such as State funds. The Secretary may waive or reduce matching fund requirements for a State, local educational agency, or other local government entity applying for a grant under this subsection, based on financial hardship. The Secretary may waive or reduce matching fund requirements for a State, local educational agency, or other local government entity applying for a grant under this subsection, based on financial hardship. A State, local educational agency, or other local government entity awarded a grant under this subtitle may use the grant funds to award subgrants to eligible local entities for carrying out grant activities. The Secretary may waive matching fund requirements for entities applying for a grant. Grant funds can be used to award subgrants to local entities. Subgrantees must comply with grant requirements. Double-dipping prevention measures are in place. Authorization of appropriations is set at $750,000,000 for fiscal year 2016. Authorization of Appropriations: $750,000,000 for fiscal year 2016 and necessary sums for fiscal years 2017 through 2025. SEC. 4. DEFINITIONS. The term "eligible local entity" in this Act refers to local educational agencies, early childhood education programs, or consortia of such entities. A "high-quality prekindergarten program" is defined as a program supported by an eligible local entity that meets specific criteria, including being equivalent to a full school day and lasting at least 5 hours. A high-quality prekindergarten program supported by an eligible local entity must serve children aged 3 or 4, or those who have attained the legal age for State-funded prekindergarten. It also requires high staff qualifications, including teachers meeting specific requirements. The prekindergarten program must be funded and have high staff qualifications, including teachers with specific educational backgrounds. To qualify for the prekindergarten program, individuals must have a bachelor's degree, demonstrate knowledge of early childhood education, engage in ongoing professional development for at least 2 years, and be enrolled in a State-approved assessment. To qualify for the prekindergarten program, individuals must have a bachelor's degree, demonstrate knowledge of early childhood education, engage in ongoing professional development for at least 2 years, and be enrolled in a State-approved educator preparation program. To qualify for the prekindergarten program, individuals must have a bachelor's degree and demonstrate competence in early childhood education. The program maintains a maximum class size of 20 children, a child to instructional staff ratio of 10 to 1, offers a full-day program, and provides developmentally appropriate learning environments with evidence-based curricula. The prekindergarten program offers a full-day program, developmentally appropriate learning environments, aligned curricula, competitive staff salaries, ongoing monitoring, and comprehensive services for children. The prekindergarten program provides full-day developmentally appropriate learning environments, aligned curricula, competitive staff salaries, ongoing monitoring, and comprehensive services for children including screenings for vision, dental, health, and development, family engagement opportunities, and assistance in obtaining services when needed. The prekindergarten program offers various opportunities for parent involvement and support services, including parent conferences, parent input on child's development, parent education, family literacy services, and nutrition services with nutritious meals aligned with requirements. The prekindergarten program provides nutrition services aligned with Child and Adult Care Food Program guidelines and offers age-appropriate nutrition education for children and families. Programs are coordinated with local educational agencies. The prekindergarten program offers physical activity programs aligned with evidence-based guidelines and additional support services for children with disabilities. The prekindergarten program provides physical activity programs aligned with evidence-based guidelines and additional support services for children with disabilities, including on-site services and high-quality professional development for staff. The program ensures teachers and assistants are trained in observation and evidence-based coaching, meeting education performance and health/safety standards. ESEA terms refer to definitions in the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965. The term "State" and "Secretary" are defined in the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965.
